index.searchable: This section offers some suggestions on how to choose the clustering algorithm suitable for specific input data.

searchablePrepared.target: This section offers some suggestions on how to choose the clustering algorithm suitable for specific input data.

index.searchable: Carrot2 comes with a number of clustering algorithms of varying performance and quality characteristics. There is also Lingo3G, a fast highly-tunable commercial algorithm that seamlessly integrates with Carrot2.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 comes with a number of clustering algorithms of varying performance and quality characteristics. There is also Lingo3G, a fast highly-tunable commercial algorithm that seamlessly integrates with Carrot2.

index.searchable: The Lingo algorithm employs term-document matrix dimensionality reduction techniques to figure out the structure of topics present in the input. The algorithm is reasonably fast and nicely separates diverse topics into separate groups. This will typically be the default algorithm you may want to use.

searchablePrepared.target: The Lingo algorithm employs term-document matrix dimensionality reduction techniques to figure out the structure of topics present in the input. The algorithm is reasonably fast and nicely separates diverse topics into separate groups. This will typically be the default algorithm you may want to use.

index.searchable: The key data structure in the STC algorithm is the Generalized Suffix Tree (GST) built for all input documents. The algorithm traverses the GST to identify words and phrases that occurred frequently in the input documents and merges sub-groups of documents with high overlap. The algorithm is very fast, even for large sets of documents, but suffers from the lack of cluster diversity.

searchablePrepared.target: The key data structure in the STC algorithm is the Generalized Suffix Tree (GST) built for all input documents. The algorithm traverses the GST to identify words and phrases that occurred frequently in the input documents and merges sub-groups of documents with high overlap. The algorithm is very fast, even for large sets of documents, but suffers from the lack of cluster diversity.

index.searchable: Bisecting k-means is an implementation of a generic cluster analysis technique, contrary to Lingo and STC which are text-specific. The algorithm attempts to recursively split the documents into smaller and smaller groups until the splits become unfeasible. The disadvantage of this algorithm is that it creates single-term labels, which are often subpar compared to phrase-based labels produced by STC or Lingo.

searchablePrepared.target: Bisecting k-means is an implementation of a generic cluster analysis technique, contrary to Lingo and STC which are text-specific. The algorithm attempts to recursively split the documents into smaller and smaller groups until the splits become unfeasible. The disadvantage of this algorithm is that it creates single-term labels, which are often subpar compared to phrase-based labels produced by STC or Lingo.

index.searchable: Lingo3G is a commercial successor to the Lingo algorithm. The algorithm offers much higher performance, lower memory consumption and many more tuning options compared to Lingo. Please refer to Carrot Search Lingo3G web site for details.

searchablePrepared.target: Lingo3G is a commercial successor to the Lingo algorithm. The algorithm offers much higher performance, lower memory consumption and many more tuning options compared to Lingo. Please refer to Carrot Search Lingo3G web site for details.

index.searchable: The following table summarizes key characteristics of each algorithm available in Carrot2.

searchablePrepared.target: The following table summarizes key characteristics of each algorithm available in Carrot2.

index.searchable: It's quite difficult to give one clear recommendation as to which algorithm is "the best". The decision is influenced by multiple criteria such as performance or cluster label legibility.

searchablePrepared.target: It's quite difficult to give one clear recommendation as to which algorithm is "the best". The decision is influenced by multiple criteria such as performance or cluster label legibility.

index.searchable: Many people (including us) have a subjective feeling that the Lingo-family of algorithms (Lingo and Lingo3G) delivers more intuitive and diverse clusters compared to other algorithms. Sometimes it is other characteristics, such as performance or cluster structure, that should be taken into account.

searchablePrepared.target: Many people (including us) have a subjective feeling that the Lingo-family of algorithms (Lingo and Lingo3G) delivers more intuitive and diverse clusters compared to other algorithms. Sometimes it is other characteristics, such as performance or cluster structure, that should be taken into account.

index.searchable: While the table above can be useful to determine which algorithm to choose, the ultimate judgment should be based on an empirical evaluation with your specific documents Make sure to also have a look at performance tuning, and quality tuning tips.

index.searchable: The quickest way to try Carrot2 is to visit the on-line demo. For more options, such as Java or REST API, read on.

searchablePrepared.target: The quickest way to try Carrot2 is to visit the on-line demo. For more options, such as Java or REST API, read on.

index.searchable: You can use the on-line demo to play with clustering of web search results provided by eTools and explore medical documents from the PubMed database.

searchablePrepared.target: You can use the on-line demo to play with clustering of web search results provided by eTools and explore medical documents from the PubMed database.

index.searchable: Part of the on-line demo is also the Carrot2 Clustering Workbench — a more advanced application for clustering content from files, Solr or Elasticsearch instances. You can use it to test Carrot2 clustering with your own content.

searchablePrepared.target: Part of the on-line demo is also the Carrot2 Clustering Workbench — a more advanced application for clustering content from files, Solr or Elasticsearch instances. You can use it to test Carrot2 clustering with your own content.

index.searchable: Please note that Workbench will transfer the contents of your files or search results to the Carrot2 server for clustering. The server will keep the data in memory for the duration of the clustering process. None of the data you submit will be permanently stored or logged.
parents: Heads up, limitations of on-line demos.

searchablePrepared.target: Please note that Workbench will transfer the contents of your files or search results to the Carrot2 server for clustering. The server will keep the data in memory for the duration of the clustering process. None of the data you submit will be permanently stored or logged.

index.searchable: Additionally, our server limits the rate and size of clustering requests to keep the service from overloading.
parents: Heads up, limitations of on-line demos.

searchablePrepared.target: Additionally, our server limits the rate and size of clustering requests to keep the service from overloading.

index.searchable: If you'd rather keep your data private or hit the processing limits, install Carrot2 on your own machine.

index.searchable: To cluster data from an Excel, OpenOffice or CSV spreadsheet:

searchablePrepared.target: To cluster data from an Excel, OpenOffice or CSV spreadsheet:

index.searchable: Make sure your spreadsheet contains one document per row. The first row will be treated as a header with field names, for example:

searchablePrepared.target: Make sure your spreadsheet contains one document per row. The first row will be treated as a header with field names, for example:

index.searchable: The spreadsheet can contain fields of all types, Workbench will try to identify the natural text fields to be used for clustering.

searchablePrepared.target: The spreadsheet can contain fields of all types, Workbench will try to identify the natural text fields to be used for clustering.

index.searchable: Open Carrot2 Clustering Workbench in a modern browser.

searchablePrepared.target: Open Carrot2 Clustering Workbench in a modern browser.

index.searchable: Choose Local file in the Data source combo box and upload the spreadsheet with your data. If necessary, refine the selection of fields fields to cluster using the Fields to cluster check boxes.

searchablePrepared.target: Choose Local file in the Data source combo box and upload the spreadsheet with your data. If necessary, refine the selection of fields fields to cluster using the Fields to cluster check boxes.

index.searchable: Press the Cluster button to generate the clusters.

searchablePrepared.target: Press the Cluster button to generate the clusters.

index.searchable: If your data is stored in an Apache Solr or Elasticsearch:

searchablePrepared.target: If your data is stored in an Apache Solr or Elasticsearch:

index.searchable: Choose Solr or Elasticsearch in the Data source combo box.

searchablePrepared.target: Choose Solr or Elasticsearch in the Data source combo box.

index.searchable: Provide the service URL of your search server and press the Connect button.

searchablePrepared.target: Provide the service URL of your search server and press the Connect button.

index.searchable: Make sure that your server is configured to emit CORS HTTP headers, otherwise Workbench will not be able to query it.

searchablePrepared.target: Make sure that your server is configured to emit CORS HTTP headers, otherwise Workbench will not be able to query it.

index.searchable: Choose the collection to search, type query and press Cluster.

searchablePrepared.target: Choose the collection to search, type query and press Cluster.

index.searchable: You can submit a file containing an array of flat JSON objects for clustering, for example:

searchablePrepared.target: You can submit a file containing an array of flat JSON objects for clustering, for example:

index.searchable: Each object represents one document. The object can contain both textual and non-textual properties, Workbench will try to determine the fields containing natural text.

searchablePrepared.target: Each object represents one document. The object can contain both textual and non-textual properties, Workbench will try to determine the fields containing natural text.

index.searchable: To cluster the contents of a JSON file:

searchablePrepared.target: To cluster the contents of a JSON file:

index.searchable: Choose Local file in the Data source combo box.

searchablePrepared.target: Choose Local file in the Data source combo box.

index.searchable: Upload or drag and drop your JSON file.

searchablePrepared.target: Upload or drag and drop your JSON file.

index.searchable: Choose the fields to cluster and press Cluster.

searchablePrepared.target: Choose the fields to cluster and press Cluster.

index.searchable: Workbench can also cluster files in the Carrot2 legacy XML format, but that format is discouraged because it does not support arbitrary field types.

searchablePrepared.target: Workbench can also cluster files in the Carrot2 legacy XML format, but that format is discouraged because it does not support arbitrary field types.

index.searchable: You can install Carrot2 on your own machine to use the search results clustering and Workbench applications without any limitations.

searchablePrepared.target: You can install Carrot2 on your own machine to use the search results clustering and Workbench applications without any limitations.

index.searchable: Dictionaries help Carrot2 to improve the quality of clustering for a specific language. This section discusses the available dictionaries and ways of tuning them to match the content you cluster.

searchablePrepared.target: Dictionaries help Carrot2 to improve the quality of clustering for a specific language. This section discusses the available dictionaries and ways of tuning them to match the content you cluster.

index.searchable: A dictionary defines a set of words or phrases that should be ignored when clustering content in a specific language. Carrot2 comes with basic dictionary files for all the supported languages. Additionally, you can provide per-request dictionaries in the REST API and configure ephemeral dictionaries using Java API.

searchablePrepared.target: A dictionary defines a set of words or phrases that should be ignored when clustering content in a specific language. Carrot2 comes with basic dictionary files for all the supported languages. Additionally, you can provide per-request dictionaries in the REST API and configure ephemeral dictionaries using Java API.

index.searchable: Carrot2 supports two types of dictionaries:

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 supports two types of dictionaries:

index.searchable: The set of words, commonly known as stop words, that should be ignored during clustering. Typically, word filters would contain function words, such as of or between.

searchablePrepared.target: The set of words, commonly known as stop words, that should be ignored during clustering. Typically, word filters would contain function words, such as of or between.

index.searchable: If a word is filtered out, it will not have influence on the clusters the algorithm creates, but may still appear in cluster labels, such as University of Washington, to aid readability.

searchablePrepared.target: If a word is filtered out, it will not have influence on the clusters the algorithm creates, but may still appear in cluster labels, such as University of Washington, to aid readability.

index.searchable: Word filters are stored in the JSON syntax for each language separately in a file named lang.word-filters.json, where lang is the name of the language, for example english.word-filters.json. Location of the dictionary files is application-specific.

searchablePrepared.target: Word filters are stored in the JSON syntax for each language separately in a file named lang.word-filters.json, where lang is the name of the language, for example english.word-filters.json. Location of the dictionary files is application-specific.

index.searchable: The set of words or phrases that must not be used as cluster labels. You can use label filters to suppress offensive or non-informative labels, such as Official website.

searchablePrepared.target: The set of words or phrases that must not be used as cluster labels. You can use label filters to suppress offensive or non-informative labels, such as Official website.

index.searchable: Label filters are stored in the JSON syntax for each language separately in a file named lang.label-filters.json, where lang is the name of the language, for example english.label-filters.json. Location of the dictionary files is application-specific.

searchablePrepared.target: Label filters are stored in the JSON syntax for each language separately in a file named lang.label-filters.json, where lang is the name of the language, for example english.label-filters.json. Location of the dictionary files is application-specific.

index.searchable: Carrot2 Document Clustering Server (REST API) loads dictionaries from an explicit non-configurable location provided below. The Java API does not dictate the location of these resources, but comes with reasonable defaults and a way to load them from a custom location.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 Document Clustering Server (REST API) loads dictionaries from an explicit non-configurable location provided below. The Java API does not dictate the location of these resources, but comes with reasonable defaults and a way to load them from a custom location.

index.searchable: The Document Clustering Server reads dictionary files from the web/service/resources directory in the server's distribution directory. For changes applied to dictionary files to take effect, you need to restart the Document Clustering Server.

searchablePrepared.target: The Document Clustering Server reads dictionary files from the web/service/resources directory in the server's distribution directory. For changes applied to dictionary files to take effect, you need to restart the Document Clustering Server.

index.searchable: By default, Carrot2 Java API will try to read dictionaries from the JAR file from which the supplier of its corresponding LanguageComponents implementation comes from. The following table presents source JARs and their resource package for the languages of the standard Carrot2 distribution.

searchablePrepared.target: By default, Carrot2 Java API will try to read dictionaries from the JAR file from which the supplier of its corresponding LanguageComponents implementation comes from. The following table presents source JARs and their resource package for the languages of the standard Carrot2 distribution.

index.searchable: Note that you should not modify the default dictionaries in-place. Instead, copy the relevant dictionaries to your application-specific location and load them from that location.

searchablePrepared.target: Note that you should not modify the default dictionaries in-place. Instead, copy the relevant dictionaries to your application-specific location and load them from that location.

index.searchable: Both the word- and label filter dictionaries use a common syntax based on matchers. An example word or label filter dictionary is shown below.

searchablePrepared.target: Both the word- and label filter dictionaries use a common syntax based on matchers. An example word or label filter dictionary is shown below.

index.searchable: A matcher entry is a description of how to determine whether a word or label should be filtered out. The exact, glob and regexp properties are optional and can contain an array of string entries for the specific matcher types, described in the following sections. If a word or a label matches any matcher of any type, it will be filtered out.

searchablePrepared.target: A matcher entry is a description of how to determine whether a word or label should be filtered out. The exact, glob and regexp properties are optional and can contain an array of string entries for the specific matcher types, described in the following sections. If a word or a label matches any matcher of any type, it will be filtered out.

index.searchable: When performing word filtering, Carrot2 will check the lower-cased version of each word against the dictionary. This is to make it easy to paste a lower-cased list of stop words into the dictionary. This also means that mixed-case entries will never match any input word.
parents: Heads up, word and label character case!

searchablePrepared.target: When performing word filtering, Carrot2 will check the lower-cased version of each word against the dictionary. This is to make it easy to paste a lower-cased list of stop words into the dictionary. This also means that mixed-case entries will never match any input word.

index.searchable: On the other hand, when performing label filtering, Carrot2 will use the case sensitive version of the label, as produced by the clustering algorithm. This means that your label filtering entries must take character case into account or use a matcher type which is oblivious of character case, such as the glob matcher.
parents: Heads up, word and label character case!

searchablePrepared.target: On the other hand, when performing label filtering, Carrot2 will use the case sensitive version of the label, as produced by the clustering algorithm. This means that your label filtering entries must take character case into account or use a matcher type which is oblivious of character case, such as the glob matcher.

index.searchable: Exact matchers require exact, case-sensitive equality between the word or phrase and the dictionary entry. Exact matcher entries are fast to parse and very fast to apply during clustering.

searchablePrepared.target: Exact matchers require exact, case-sensitive equality between the word or phrase and the dictionary entry. Exact matcher entries are fast to parse and very fast to apply during clustering.

index.searchable: The above label dictionary definitions will match labels DevOps and Windows 2000, but will not match Devops or Windows 2000 machine.

searchablePrepared.target: The above label dictionary definitions will match labels DevOps and Windows 2000, but will not match Devops or Windows 2000 machine.

index.searchable: For case-insensitive matching, use glob matchers (preferably) or case-insensitive regular expression matchers.

searchablePrepared.target: For case-insensitive matching, use glob matchers (preferably) or case-insensitive regular expression matchers.

index.searchable: Glob matcher allows simple word-based wildcard matching. The primary use case of the glob matcher is case-insensitive matching of literal phrases, as well as "begins with…", "ends with…" or "contains…" types of expressions. Glob matcher entries are fast to parse and very fast to apply.

searchablePrepared.target: Glob matcher allows simple word-based wildcard matching. The primary use case of the glob matcher is case-insensitive matching of literal phrases, as well as "begins with…", "ends with…" or "contains…" types of expressions. Glob matcher entries are fast to parse and very fast to apply.

index.searchable: Each entry must consist of one or more space-separated tokens.

searchablePrepared.target: Each entry must consist of one or more space-separated tokens.

index.searchable: A token is a sequence of arbitrary characters, such as words, numbers, identifiers.

searchablePrepared.target: A token is a sequence of arbitrary characters, such as words, numbers, identifiers.

index.searchable: Matching is case-insensitive by default. Letter case normalization is performed based on the ROOT Java locale, which performs language-neutral case conflation according to Unicode rules.

searchablePrepared.target: Matching is case-insensitive by default. Letter case normalization is performed based on the ROOT Java locale, which performs language-neutral case conflation according to Unicode rules.

index.searchable: A token put in single or double quotes, for example "Rating***" is taken literally: matching is case-sensitive, * character inside quoted tokens is allowed and compared literally.

searchablePrepared.target: A token put in single or double quotes, for example "Rating***" is taken literally: matching is case-sensitive, * character inside quoted tokens is allowed and compared literally.

index.searchable: To include quote characters in the token, escape them with the \ character, for example: \"information\".

searchablePrepared.target: To include quote characters in the token, escape them with the \ character, for example: \"information\".

index.searchable: The following wildcard-matching tokens are recognized:

searchablePrepared.target: The following wildcard-matching tokens are recognized:

index.searchable: The ? token matches exactly one (any) word (possessive operator).

searchablePrepared.target: The ? token matches exactly one (any) word (possessive operator).

index.searchable: The * token matches zero or more words (possessive operator).

searchablePrepared.target: The * token matches zero or more words (possessive operator).

index.searchable: The *? token matches zero or more words (reluctant operator).

searchablePrepared.target: The *? token matches zero or more words (reluctant operator).

index.searchable: The + token matches one or more words (possessive operator). This operator is functionally equivalent to: ? *.

searchablePrepared.target: The + token matches one or more words (possessive operator). This operator is functionally equivalent to: ? *.

index.searchable: The +? token matches one or more words (reluctant operator). This operator is functionally equivalent to: ? *?.

searchablePrepared.target: The +? token matches one or more words (reluctant operator). This operator is functionally equivalent to: ? *?.

index.searchable: A few restrictions apply to wildcard operators.

searchablePrepared.target: A few restrictions apply to wildcard operators.

index.searchable: Wildcard characters (*, +) cannot be used to express prefixes or suffixes. For example, programm*, is not supported.

searchablePrepared.target: Wildcard characters (*, +) cannot be used to express prefixes or suffixes. For example, programm*, is not supported.

index.searchable: *? and +? wildcards are reluctant matchers in regular expression matching sense: that is, they match the minimal sequence of tokens until the next token in the pattern.

searchablePrepared.target: *? and +? wildcards are reluctant matchers in regular expression matching sense: that is, they match the minimal sequence of tokens until the next token in the pattern.

index.searchable: * and + wildcards are possessive matchers in regular expression matching sense: that is, they match the maximum sequence of tokens until the next token in the pattern.

searchablePrepared.target: * and + wildcards are possessive matchers in regular expression matching sense: that is, they match the maximum sequence of tokens until the next token in the pattern.

index.searchable: Greedy operators are not supported.

searchablePrepared.target: Greedy operators are not supported.

index.searchable: The regular expression matcher checks words or labels against a list of regular expressions you provide.

index.searchable: Regular expression-based matching is a powerful mechanism, but it can also result in a dramatic decrease of clustering performance. Therefore, it should be used only when a similar effect cannot be achieved by reasonable number of exact and glob matching entries.

index.searchable: Providing per-request dictionaries is possible both in the Java API, where the ephemeral dictionaries is a better term, and in the REST API. index.searchable: Please note that using per-request dictionaries will incur an extra performance cost associated with parsing the provided dictionary entries. searchablePrepared.target: Request Templates

index.searchable: How to create a request template?

searchablePrepared.target: How to create a request template?

index.searchable: This section introduces request templates and why they can be useful to detach algorithm configuration from actual clustering requests.

searchablePrepared.target: This section introduces request templates and why they can be useful to detach algorithm configuration from actual clustering requests.

index.searchable: As mentioned in the introduction, a clustering query is self-contained and must carry the three required elements: algorithm name, language and documents to be clustered. In practice, the first two elements will rarely change – once the algorithm for a particular task is chosen, it will probably remain constant for all clustering requests. In situations like this we can pull out the constant part of the query into a template and use basic composition with the body of a query to get the final request.

searchablePrepared.target: As mentioned in the introduction, a clustering query is self-contained and must carry the three required elements: algorithm name, language and documents to be clustered. In practice, the first two elements will rarely change – once the algorithm for a particular task is chosen, it will probably remain constant for all clustering requests. In situations like this we can pull out the constant part of the query into a template and use basic composition with the body of a query to get the final request.

index.searchable: Another useful application of templates is to detach the algorithm and its configuration from the logic that queries the clustering service or to group different algorithms and their tuning variants under much easier to remember aliases.

searchablePrepared.target: Another useful application of templates is to detach the algorithm and its configuration from the logic that queries the clustering service or to group different algorithms and their tuning variants under much easier to remember aliases.

index.searchable: SimpleLabelAssigner

searchablePrepared.target: SimpleLabelAssigner

index.searchable: A simple and fast label assigner. For each base vector chooses the label that maximizes the base vector--label term vector cosine similarity. Different vectors can get the same label assigned, which means the number of final labels (after duplicate removal) may be smaller than the number of base vectors on input.

searchablePrepared.target: A simple and fast label assigner. For each base vector chooses the label that maximizes the base vector--label term vector cosine similarity. Different vectors can get the same label assigned, which means the number of final labels (after duplicate removal) may be smaller than the number of base vectors on input.

index.searchable: UniqueLabelAssigner

searchablePrepared.target: UniqueLabelAssigner

index.searchable: Assigns unique labels to each base vector using a greedy algorithm. For each base vector chooses the label that maximizes the base vector--label term vector cosine similarity and has not been previously selected. Once a label is selected, it will not be used to label any other vector. This algorithm does not create duplicate cluster labels, which usually means that this assignment method will create more clusters than org.carrot2.clustering.lingo.SimpleLabelAssigner. This method is slightly slower than org.carrot2.clustering.lingo.SimpleLabelAssigner.

This algorithm does not create duplicate cluster labels, which usually means that this assignment method will create more clusters than org.carrot2.clustering.lingo.SimpleLabelAssigner. This method is slightly slower than org.carrot2.clustering.lingo.SimpleLabelAssigner.

index.searchable: Carrot2 algorithms should produce reasonably good clusters out-of-the box for most inputs. If you'd like to fine-tune the quality or performance of clustering, this article discusses the possible approaches.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 algorithms should produce reasonably good clusters out-of-the box for most inputs. If you'd like to fine-tune the quality or performance of clustering, this article discusses the possible approaches.

index.searchable: The quality of clusters and their labels largely depends on the quality of documents provided on the input. Although there is no general rule for optimum document content, below are some tips worth considering.

searchablePrepared.target: The quality of clusters and their labels largely depends on the quality of documents provided on the input. Although there is no general rule for optimum document content, below are some tips worth considering.

index.searchable: Carrot2 is designed for small to medium collections of documents. Carrot2 algorithms perform in-memory clustering. For this reason, as a rule of thumb, Carrot2 should successfully deal with up to a thousand of documents, a few paragraphs each. For algorithms designed to process millions of documents, check out the Apache Mahout project or Carrot Search Lingo4G.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 is designed for small to medium collections of documents. Carrot2 algorithms perform in-memory clustering. For this reason, as a rule of thumb, Carrot2 should successfully deal with up to a thousand of documents, a few paragraphs each. For algorithms designed to process millions of documents, check out the Apache Mahout project or Carrot Search Lingo4G.

index.searchable: Provide a minimum of 100 documents. Carrot2 clustering algorithms work better with increasing amount of data. A hundred documents on input is probably the minimum for any statistical significance of features discovered by the algorithm. In general, an optimum number of documents would probably fall between 100 and a few thousands. More than that may cause problems due to in-memory processing.

searchablePrepared.target: Provide a minimum of 100 documents. Carrot2 clustering algorithms work better with increasing amount of data. A hundred documents on input is probably the minimum for any statistical significance of features discovered by the algorithm. In general, an optimum number of documents would probably fall between 100 and a few thousands. More than that may cause problems due to in-memory processing.

index.searchable: Provide query-context snippets instead of entire documents. If the input documents are a result of some search query, provide contextual snippets related to that query (similar to what web search engines return), instead of full document content. Not only will this speed up processing, but should also guide the clustering algorithm to discover query-related spectrum of topics.

searchablePrepared.target: Provide query-context snippets instead of entire documents. If the input documents are a result of some search query, provide contextual snippets related to that query (similar to what web search engines return), instead of full document content. Not only will this speed up processing, but should also guide the clustering algorithm to discover query-related spectrum of topics.

index.searchable: Minimize noise in the input documents. All kinds of noisy fragments in the input like truncated sentences, random alphanumerical strings or repeated boilerplate may decrease the quality of cluster labels. If you are extracting query context for clustering, retrieving complete sentences instead of truncated fragments should improve cluster labels even further.

searchablePrepared.target: Minimize noise in the input documents. All kinds of noisy fragments in the input like truncated sentences, random alphanumerical strings or repeated boilerplate may decrease the quality of cluster labels. If you are extracting query context for clustering, retrieving complete sentences instead of truncated fragments should improve cluster labels even further.

index.searchable: The default settings that come with each algorithm are good for an average case. Each clustering algorithm comes with a number of parameters affecting its output and runtime characteristics. See the algorithm's reference page, such as Lingo parameters, for a list and description of the parameters.

searchablePrepared.target: The default settings that come with each algorithm are good for an average case. Each clustering algorithm comes with a number of parameters affecting its output and runtime characteristics. See the algorithm's reference page, such as Lingo parameters, for a list and description of the parameters.

index.searchable: You can easily adjust parameters in Java API. If you call the REST API from Java code, a robust way to override parameters is to use request model classes.

searchablePrepared.target: You can easily adjust parameters in Java API. If you call the REST API from Java code, a robust way to override parameters is to use request model classes.

index.searchable: When using the REST API directly, an easy way to get the parameters JSON object is to use Carrot2 Workbench: set the desired values using the left-hand-side panel and then press the parameter export button to get the JSON with just the parameters that are different from defaults.

index.searchable: For example, if clustering documents from the medical domain, certain expressions and terms may be obvious and trivial to the domain. Forming clusters out of these wouldn't be of any value to the users. By excluding such expressions the algorithms are guided to look for other, perhaps more interesting alternative content.

index.searchable: Carrot2 clustering algorithms have been designed to work really fast but the trade-off is that they store all the data structures in memory. The size of the Java virtual machine's heap will increase quickly with longer overall size of input text. Also, the more documents you put on input and the longer the documents are, the longer the clustering will take.

The size of the Java virtual machine's heap will increase quickly with longer overall size of input text. Also, the more documents you put on input and the longer the documents are, the longer the clustering will take.

index.searchable: Below are a few generic guidelines on improving clustering performance.

index.searchable: In many cases when the input collection of documents is too large to cluster as a whole, dividing the input into smaller batches (or sampling smaller batches from the input), then clustering separately and finally merging based on cluster label text gives very reasonable results.
parents: Batch and merge smaller clustering runs

searchablePrepared.target: In many cases when the input collection of documents is too large to cluster as a whole, dividing the input into smaller batches (or sampling smaller batches from the input), then clustering separately and finally merging based on cluster label text gives very reasonable results.

index.searchable: The above approach works because cluster labels recurring in smaller batches are very likely to be significant for the entire collection. The downside is that very small clusters containing just a few documents are likely to be lost during this process.

Below are some parameter customization suggestions you should consider. You will likely need to experiment a bit to adjust their values to match the size of your particular input.

index.searchable: Increase the minimum document frequency (minimum number of occurrences) of terms and phrases to a higher value. Something like 0.5% of the number of documents will typically work. For example, for a document collection of 5000 documents set the parameter to 25.

searchablePrepared.target: Increase the minimum document frequency (minimum number of occurrences) of terms and phrases to a higher value. Something like 0.5% of the number of documents will typically work. For example, for a document collection of 5000 documents set the parameter to 25.

index.searchable: For algorithm.matrixReducer.factorizationFactory implementations that support this parameter, lower factorizationQuality. This will cause the matrix factorization algorithm to perform fewer iterations and hence complete quicker.

searchablePrepared.target: For algorithm.matrixReducer.factorizationFactory implementations that support this parameter, lower factorizationQuality. This will cause the matrix factorization algorithm to perform fewer iterations and hence complete quicker.

index.searchable: Alternatively, you can set algorithm.matrixReducer.factorizationFactory to an implementation of PartialSingularValueDecompositionFactory, which is slightly faster than the other factorizations and does not have any explicit factorizationQuality parameter.

index.searchable: Lower maximum matrix size in matrixBuilder. This will cause the matrix factorization algorithm to complete quicker and use less memory. The tradeoff is that with small matrix sizes, Lingo may not be able to discover smaller clusters.

index.searchable: This release changes the lexical data dictionary formats, adds ephemeral per-request dictionaries and introduces minor adjustments to Java and REST APIs.

searchablePrepared.target: This release changes the lexical data dictionary formats, adds ephemeral per-request dictionaries and introduces minor adjustments to Java and REST APIs.

index.searchable: Carrot2 Clustering Workbench has been rewritten as a browser-based application.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 Clustering Workbench has been rewritten as a browser-based application.

index.searchable: You can use Workbench to cluster documents from local XML, JSON, Excel and CSV files, as well as Solr and Elasticsearch instances. A set of sliders is available to change clustering parameters in real time; you can also export the parameters JSON ready for pasting into REST API requests. Finally, you can export the clustering results as JSON or Excel spreadsheet.

searchablePrepared.target: You can use Workbench to cluster documents from local XML, JSON, Excel and CSV files, as well as Solr and Elasticsearch instances. A set of sliders is available to change clustering parameters in real time; you can also export the parameters JSON ready for pasting into REST API requests. Finally, you can export the clustering results as JSON or Excel spreadsheet.

index.searchable: Carrot2 word and label filtering dictionaries are now stored in the JSON format. This change adds more expressive matching modes, such as globs for simple phrase-level filtering or regular expressions for complete control of the filtering. Please refer to the dictionaries section for an in-depth overview of what's available.

searchablePrepared.target: Carrot2 word and label filtering dictionaries are now stored in the JSON format. This change adds more expressive matching modes, such as globs for simple phrase-level filtering or regular expressions for complete control of the filtering. Please refer to the dictionaries section for an in-depth overview of what's available.

index.searchable: As a follow-up, the plain-text dictionaries have been deprecated and the file naming convention for the default dictionary files has changed. A dictionary file conversion utility is available.

searchablePrepared.target: As a follow-up, the plain-text dictionaries have been deprecated and the file naming convention for the default dictionary files has changed. A dictionary file conversion utility is available.

index.searchable: Per-request (ephemeral) label and word filtering support has been added. This feature allows passing per-request word and cluster label filters to be applied in addition to the default language resources. See ephemeral dictionary section in the Java API and REST API sections for more information.

searchablePrepared.target: Per-request (ephemeral) label and word filtering support has been added. This feature allows passing per-request word and cluster label filters to be applied in addition to the default language resources. See ephemeral dictionary section in the Java API and REST API sections for more information.

index.searchable: As a follow-up to the JSON dictionaries new feature, the plain-text-based format has been deprecated.

searchablePrepared.target: As a follow-up to the JSON dictionaries new feature, the plain-text-based format has been deprecated.

index.searchable: File naming convention for default language resources has changed. For backward compatibility, if old resources can be found in the resource lookup location, they will still be used and a warning will be issued via Java logging system.

searchablePrepared.target: File naming convention for default language resources has changed. For backward compatibility, if old resources can be found in the resource lookup location, they will still be used and a warning will be issued via Java logging system.

index.searchable: If you have language resources in the old format, please convert them to the JSON format. A simple utility is included in Carrot2 core JAR and can help with the conversion. Just run it with:

searchablePrepared.target: If you have language resources in the old format, please convert them to the JSON format. A simple utility is included in Carrot2 core JAR and can help with the conversion. Just run it with:

index.searchable: Where dir points to a directory with old resources. New resources in their corresponding naming convention will be written alongside old resources. The old resource must be manually deleted once the conversion completes successfully.

searchablePrepared.target: Where dir points to a directory with old resources. New resources in their corresponding naming convention will be written alongside old resources. The old resource must be manually deleted once the conversion completes successfully.

index.searchable: The /service/list endpoint of the REST API now returns the language and algorithm for all of the available request templates.

searchablePrepared.target: The /service/list endpoint of the REST API now returns the language and algorithm for all of the available request templates.

index.searchable: The response format of the endpoint has changed. Previously, the templates element was a list of template names, now it will contain an object with template names as keys and template content as values, for example:

searchablePrepared.target: The response format of the endpoint has changed. Previously, the templates element was a list of template names, now it will contain an object with template names as keys and template content as values, for example:

index.searchable: Lingo algorithm's filter parameters have been changed from Booleans to proper objects with a dedicated enabled parameter. Unless you used these attributes explicitly, no action is needed.

searchablePrepared.target: Lingo algorithm's filter parameters have been changed from Booleans to proper objects with a dedicated enabled parameter. Unless you used these attributes explicitly, no action is needed.

index.searchable: The LexicalData interface (LanguageComponents component) has been split into two independent components: StopwordFilter and LabelFilter. The default implementations and abstract classes have been changed accordingly.

searchablePrepared.target: The LexicalData interface (LanguageComponents component) has been split into two independent components: StopwordFilter and LabelFilter. The default implementations and abstract classes have been changed accordingly.

index.searchable: REST API built-in server now supports GZIP compression.

searchablePrepared.target: REST API built-in server now supports GZIP compression.

index.searchable: Added clustering and request processing time information to clustering response. This information is optional and is returned when the serviceInfoHTTP parameter is enabled on a clustering request.

searchablePrepared.target: Added clustering and request processing time information to clustering response. This information is optional and is returned when the serviceInfoHTTP parameter is enabled on a clustering request.

index.searchable: Improved support for the Java module system by providing the Automatic-Module-Name entry in JAR manifests.

searchablePrepared.target: Improved support for the Java module system by providing the Automatic-Module-Name entry in JAR manifests.

searchablePrepared.target: This release enhances glob dictionaries with new wildcard operators, brings GUI cleanups and improvements to the Workbench and fixes bugs in the (low-level) algorithm loader API.

index.searchable: This release is not a drop-in replacement for Carrot2 4.1.x: if you have any custom language components (dictionaries) they may need to be reviewed because the behavior of the glob matcher and regular expression matcher have changed.

searchablePrepared.target: This release is not a drop-in replacement for Carrot2 4.1.x: if you have any custom language components (dictionaries) they may need to be reviewed because the behavior of the glob matcher and regular expression matcher have changed.

index.searchable: The glob matcher dictionary has been rewritten and improved to support more operators (one-or-more, one, possessive and reluctant matches).

searchablePrepared.target: The glob matcher dictionary has been rewritten and improved to support more operators (one-or-more, one, possessive and reluctant matches).

index.searchable: This feature does change the API (see API changes below).

searchablePrepared.target: This feature does change the API (see API changes below).

index.searchable: The DCS launcher now supports the --pid-file option which emits the process PID. This option can be useful for various service wrappers.

searchablePrepared.target: The DCS launcher now supports the --pid-file option which emits the process PID. This option can be useful for various service wrappers.

index.searchable: The DCS launcher now supports the --idle-time option which sets the default server side socket idle time expiry.

searchablePrepared.target: The DCS launcher now supports the --idle-time option which sets the default server side socket idle time expiry.

index.searchable: The new syntax added to the glob matcher dictionary may cause small incompatibilities with any previously defined dictionaries. The single * operator is now possessive (matches as many tokens as possible) and the previous behavior is now available under a reluctant variant of: *?.

searchablePrepared.target: The new syntax added to the glob matcher dictionary may cause small incompatibilities with any previously defined dictionaries. The single * operator is now possessive (matches as many tokens as possible) and the previous behavior is now available under a reluctant variant of: *?.

index.searchable: The regular expression dictionary now triggers on any sub-sequence match (not entire label match). This behavior was actually documented and was the default in Carrot2 release prior to 2.0.0 so it's a regression.

searchablePrepared.target: The regular expression dictionary now triggers on any sub-sequence match (not entire label match). This behavior was actually documented and was the default in Carrot2 release prior to 2.0.0 so it's a regression.

index.searchable: If you need to revert to the previous behavior, add start and end requirement directly to your regular expressions: ^(previous-regexp)$.

searchablePrepared.target: If you need to revert to the previous behavior, add start and end requirement directly to your regular expressions: ^(previous-regexp)$.
